title: Diploma - Project Management in Practice
headline: Improve your project management skills for managing complex technical projects with this free online course.
description: This online technical project management course will teach you about practical project management. It covers the fundamental principles and practices in project management including basic concepts such as project selection, initiation and procurement. You will study leadership, planning, scheduling, risks, and costs and budgets. You will also learn about resource allocation, monitoring, and control needed to manage complex technical projects.

courseDescription:
Improve your technical project management skills with Alison’s free online course 'Diploma - Project Management in Practice'. This course covers the basic principles and practices essential in effective modern project management. The course will improve your project management skills for managing complex technical projects.

The course begins with an overview of the concepts in modern technical project management, and a basic introduction to Lean and Agile software development. The course then describes the various processes involved in project management such as project selection, initiation, procurement, leadership, planning, scheduling, risks, costs and budgets, resource allocation, monitoring and control. Finally, you will learn about negotiation as a critical skill, project management growth, and project closure.

This course is aimed at meeting the interests and needs of career professionals who value practical principles and guidance, and students who wish to build on past experiences and improve on effective strategies for managing complex technical projects. This includes an emphasis on applying concepts of project management to real-world issues. So, why wait? Start the course today and learn how to become an effective project manager!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. • Learning Outcomes

    • Identify essential roles and qualities of project managers

    • Explain the project’s complete life cycle and project outcome, success and sustainability

    • Discuss the basics of Agile software development such as product stories and sprints

  • Modern Technical Project Management
  • Introduction
  •  
    Projects are by nature ephemeral, that is, they come and go, depending on an organization’s needs, and eventually end. A project, according to the Cambridge English Dictionary, is “a piece of planned work or activity that is completed over a period of time and intended to achieve a particular aim” (CED, 2018).

    Due to the fleeting nature of projects, organizations with sub-optimal project management expertise often fail to develop systematic processes for managing their projects. Therefore, once a project has been completed, everyone moves on, preparing for the next project, barely glancing at what did and didn’t work in the previous project. 

    Such organizations lack a coherent approach to project management—“the application of processes, methods, knowledge, skills, and experience to achieve the project objectives” (Association for Project Management, n.d.). This lack of a systematic approach is problematic in technical fields, leading to a very high rate of failure for technical projects across numerous industries.

  • Technical Project Management
  • Introduction
  •  
    In his 1907 book Creative Evolution, the French philosopher, Henri Bergson investigated the nature of human creativity and its relation to order. According to Bergson, by “order” we mean a mechanistic, predetermined, linear relationship between things. Event A leads to Event B; B leads to C; C leads to D; and so on, with no possibility of variation or adaptation. 

    Also, we tend to consider creativity as something that arises only in a state of disorder—that is, when no type of order is evident. The free-thinking artist is a stereotype founded in this way of thinking. But Bergson argued that the disorder we associate with creativity is really just another type of order. Again, we look at Alexander Laufer, who got some crucial insights on project management from Bergson’s work, which he summarized as follows:

    Bergson claimed that there is no such thing as a disorder, but rather two sorts of order: geometric and living order. While in ”geometric order” Bergson related to the traditional concept of order, in ”living order” he referred to phenomena such as the creativity of an individual, a work of art, or the mess in my office. (Laufer, 2012)

    Throughout this course, we will examine and compare geometric order to living order, with the goal of developing a creative, realistic, functional approach to project management.

  • Project Life Cycle and Living Order
  • Introduction
  • If you begin to recognize the dynamic nature of living order, you will then start to appreciate the potential for change embedded throughout a project’s life cycle. This is also valid for the result of a project—whether it’s a building, a new smartphone, or software. The product, or result, of a project is created, maintained, adapted, updated, and demolished/retired by various projects during its life.

    Each of these projects is subject to the living order uncertainty, increasing the difficulty of determining what the exact result of a project will be like in the future, and if it will actually be suitable for its intended purpose. This, in turn, complicates the planning phase for any project, especially for items that are ultimately judged by how easily it can be dismantled and disposed of, or recycled and reused.

    For example, Figure 1-3 shows the life cycle of a building. At the initial stage, the making stage, this is the project manager’s domain who supervises the construction. Once the building is completed, the project manager then moves on to other work, but the building has just begun its functional life. During the operating/using/changing stages, the occupants of the building either enjoy or suffer from the decisions the project manager made throughout the making stage. Then comes the retirement/reuse stage, when the building will possibly be demolished and something else constructed in its place. At that point, the whole life cycle starts again.

Then comes the retirement/reuse stage, when the building will possibly be demolished and something else constructed in its place. At that point, the whole life cycle starts again.
  • Project Life Cycle and Living Order
  • Introduction
  • If you begin to recognize the dynamic nature of living order, you will then start to appreciate the potential for change embedded throughout a project’s life cycle. This is also valid for the result of a project—whether it’s a building, a new smartphone, or software. The product, or result, of a project is created, maintained, adapted, updated, and demolished/retired by various projects during its life.

    Each of these projects is subject to the living order uncertainty, increasing the difficulty of determining what the exact result of a project will be like in the future, and if it will actually be suitable for its intended purpose. This, in turn, complicates the planning phase for any project, especially for items that are ultimately judged by how easily it can be dismantled and disposed of, or recycled and reused.

    For example, Figure 1-3 shows the life cycle of a building. At the initial stage, the making stage, this is the project manager’s domain who supervises the construction. Once the building is completed, the project manager then moves on to other work, but the building has just begun its functional life. During the operating/using/changing stages, the occupants of the building either enjoy or suffer from the decisions the project manager made throughout the making stage. Then comes the retirement/reuse stage, when the building will possibly be demolished and something else constructed in its place. At that point, the whole life cycle starts again.

  • Roles of a Project Manager
  •  
    Practically speaking, what does all this talk about change and unpredictability entail for a real-life project manager? Throughout this course, we will be looking at ways to accommodate the realities of living order in the day-to-day tasks involved in technical project management.

    For example, in module 6, we’ll discuss pull planning; an adaptive, recursive form of planning that prioritizes regular updating to reflect current conditions. But for now, let’s discuss some general principles for successful project management in a living order world.

    In an article for MIT Sloan Management Review, Alexander Laufer, Edward Hoffman, Jeffrey Russell, and Scott Cameron reveal how successful project managers combine traditional management methods with newer, more flexible approaches to achieve better outcomes (Laufer et al. 2015). Their research showed that successful project managers should adopt these four vital roles:
    • Develop collaboration among project participants: “Most projects are characterized by an inherent incompatibility: the various parties to the project are loosely coupled, whereas the tasks themselves are tightly coupled. When unexpected events affect one task, many other interdependent tasks are quickly affected. Yet the direct responsibility for these tasks is distributed among various loosely coupled parties, who are unable to coordinate their actions and provide a timely response. Project success, therefore, requires both interdependence and trust among the various parties” (Laufer et al. 2015, 46)

  • Lean: Eliminating Waste in Living Order
  • Introduction
  •  
    Traditionally, geometric order project management is often inefficient, leading to a waste of time, money, resources, and labor. However, Lean is a business model and project management philosophy that provides a means to streamline projects while providing for the flexibility needed to deal with unexpected events. 

    Built on ideas and practices developed at Toyota after World War II, it stresses creating value for the customer while eliminating waste through the efficient workflow from one project phase to another. Moreover, Lean is a way of thinking. In their essential book on the topic, James P. Womack and Daniel T. Jones describe Lean thinking as follows:

    It provides a way to specify value, line up value-creating actions in the best sequence, conduct these activities without interruption whenever someone requests them, and perform them more and more effectively. In short, Lean thinking is Lean because it provides a way to do more and more with less and less—less human effort, less equipment, less time, and less space—while coming closer and closer to providing customers with exactly what they want. (Womack and Jones 2003, 15)

    Throughout this course, we will be discussing Lean extensively. To get started, we will focus on two fundamental Lean ideas: value and waste.

  • Agile: Fast Feedback in Living Order
  • Introduction
  • Lean was originally developed in the manufacturing world but has now been adopted in many industries. In software development, a related methodology, Agile, is becoming increasingly popular. In essence, it is an IT version of Lean. Although Agile originated from software development, companies have also expanded its use into a variety of project types, including product development, capital projects, and service projects.

    The many flavors of Agile include:
    • Agile Scrum: Designed for completing complex projects, as described on ScrumGuides, Scrum is the most widely used form of Agile. When people talk about Agile, they are usually talking about Scrum (https://www.scrumguides.org/scrum-guide.html)
    • Extreme Programming: Emphasizes short development cycles with frequent releases of software for evaluation, after which a new development cycle begins. You can read more about extreme programming at “Extreme Programming: A Gentle Introduction“ (http://www.extremeprogramming.org/)
    • Rapid Product Development: Emphasizes “simultaneous, coordinated activities by multi-functional teams, striving for smooth transitions between phases for the most rapid time-to-market” (ORC International: Expert Advisory Services). You can read more about Rapid Product Development in this “Introduction to Rapid Product Development” (http://www.factoryoffactories.com/ressources/RPDmanager.pdf)

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Practical Tips
  • Below are some practical tips adapted from this module:
    • Prepare to use both geometric and living order techniques: Projects are often conceived and planned in geometric order, with the naïve assumption of events unfolding predictably. Then reality hits, and they are executed amidst the uncertainties of living order. However, eventually, as projects unfold, and you begin to learn what to expect, they can become more geometric. Be prepared to move back and forth among geometric and living order techniques, adapting to the situation as necessary
    • When working in geometric order, focus on the following:
      - Define project success
      - Establish a project timeline
      - Ensure the project delivers the specified results
      - Constantly check your progress against the project schedule
      - Regularly check costs against the project budget
      - Periodically pause to make sure the project really is unfolding in geometric order and hasn’t shifted to living order

  • Lesson Summary
  • In technical project management, bear in mind that:
    • Projects progress in unique and dynamic contexts that requires a flexible and adaptable approach in project management
    • Organizations often develop projects in the unpredictability of the living order and try to execute them in the systematic geometric order. Good project managers should always consider the unpredictable, permanent world in which projects are executed
    • The understanding of ‘project success’ is expanded by realizing that a project’s life cycle involves more than the making stage
    • The Lean project management approach aims at maximizing value for the client and eliminating wastages whereas the Agile project management approach involves strategies which encourage flexibility required in the living order
  •  
    Learning Outcomes
  •  
    Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
  •  
    • Discuss terms related to strategy and portfolios
    • Define basic concepts related to strategy
    • Differentiate between operational effectiveness and strategy
    • Enumerate various factors that hinder strategy execution
    • Identify problems encountered in aligning projects with strategy
    • Discuss difficulties in terminating or killing projects
    • Suggest methods of identifying a poorly conceived project

  • Do the Right Thing
  • Introduction
  • Choosing the right projects is the first step to take in effective project management and execution. Although you may not be able to control which project your organization chooses, you still have to understand the basis of the project selection by your organization for effective project management and contribution to decisions on how to develop and, if necessary, terminate a project. Your study of technical project management will primarily focus on doing things the right way. Here, we will concentrate on doing the right thing from the start.

    Let’s start with some basic definitions:
    • Project: The “temporary initiatives that companies put into place alongside their ongoing operations to achieve specific goals. They are clearly defined packages of work, bound by deadlines and endowed with resources including budgets, people, and facilities” (Morgan, Levitt and Malek 2007, 3). This is a more expansive definition than the Cambridge English Dictionary definition introduced in Module 1—“a piece of planned work or activity that is completed over a period of time and intended to achieve a particular aim”—because we will be focusing on the trade-offs necessitated by deadlines and limited resources
    • Program: “A cluster of interconnected projects” (Morgan, Levitt and Malek 2007, 9)
    • Portfolio: The “array of investments in projects and programs a company chooses to pursue” (Morgan, Levitt and Malek 2007, 3)
    • Strategy: According to Merriam-Webster, “a careful plan or method for achieving a particular goal usually over a long period of time”

  • Lean and Strategy
  • Introduction
  • In Module 1, you learned that the Lean approach to project management focuses on maximizing value for the customer and eliminating waste. Basically, it is a means of streamlining operational effectiveness, but it also offers major strategic benefits. In truly Lean organizations, managers have the time and autonomy to focus on high-level issues. The focus on flexibility makes it easy for a Lean organization to pivot to new opportunities that are in line with the organization’s strategy. In an article for Planet Lean, Michael Ballé explains:

    Lean is often reduced to a manufacturing tactic because it doesn’t fit the frame of traditional strategy. Lean can’t tell you which niche to pursue, it can’t help you build a roadmap, and it won’t tell you what reasonable objectives are or how to incentivize people to get them.

    Lean, however, is the key to creating dynamic strategies built on more mindful care of customers, more dynamic objectives (reduce the waste by half every year), faster learning, greater involvement of all people all the time for stronger morale, more determined focus on higher-level goals and quicker exploitation of unexpected opportunities. (Ballé 2016)

  • Aligning Projects with Strategy
  • Introduction
  • Organizations use projects as a means of putting a strategy into operation. Ultimately, effective strategy execution involves engaging in the right projects. This means aligning projects and initiatives with the overall goals of the company. Bear it in mind that taking a long-term approach to executing a new strategy involves a living order obligation to an amount of uncertainty in the short-term. 

    Also, it may take some time for everybody to conform to the new plan and in the meantime the operations may not proceed as planned. But if you keep your eye on the North Star of your organization’s strategy, you can help your team navigate the unsteady waters of change.

    There are two levels of project selection: the portfolio and the project levels. On the portfolio level, management aims to make sure that all projects in a portfolio support the organization’s larger strategy. In other words, management’s emphasis is on optimizing its portfolio of projects. According to Morgan et al., portfolio optimization is “the difficult and iterative process of choosing and constantly monitoring what the organization commits to do” (Morgan et al. 2007, 167).

Bear it in mind that taking a long-term approach to executing a new strategy involves a living order obligation to an amount of uncertainty in the short-term. 

    Also, it may take some time for everybody to conform to the new plan and in the meantime the operations may not proceed as planned. But if you keep your eye on the North Star of your organization’s strategy, you can help your team navigate the unsteady waters of change.

    There are two levels of project selection: the portfolio and the project levels. On the portfolio level, management aims to make sure that all projects in a portfolio support the organization’s larger strategy. In other words, management’s emphasis is on optimizing its portfolio of projects. According to Morgan et al., portfolio optimization is “the difficult and iterative process of choosing and constantly monitoring what the organization commits to do” (Morgan et al. 2007, 167).
  • Knowing When to Say No
  • Introduction
  • The level of learning increases with the amount of screens or gates a project goes through. In the end, what you learn about the project can lead you to determine that the project is unviable. However, people would have become invested in the project at this point. Naturally, they would want it to be a success and therefore be unable to see the downsides clearly. In other words, they suffer from a cognitive bias known as groupthink, which causes people to adopt a belief simply because a significant number of people hold that same belief.

    This problem can be worsened if someone with an especially charismatic personality has taken on the role of the project’s chief advocate, or project champion, in the early stages of evaluation. If the project champion then becomes the project manager, terminating the project can be more difficult, once the project manager becomes absorbed in the technical details and loses track of the larger organizational issues (Kerzner and Kerzner, 24).

    At this point, it might be wise to appoint an exit champion, or a manager who is responsible for advocating the termination of a project if he or she thinks that is in the best interests of the organization, regardless of the desires of the project team members. Even if your organization doesn’t allow for an officially designated exit champion, it probably has some sort of project selection process that includes points at which a project can be killed.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Practical Tips
  • Below are some practical tips:
    • Align projects to your organization’s strategy: Make conscious efforts in linking your organization’s strategy to every project you manage, with the goal of helping all stakeholders understand their larger purpose. For example, your organization might settle on a strategy of pursuing government contracts. This would involve learning everything about the very geometric-order world of government contracts, which calls for careful adherence to the details of an RFP, and then pursuing government contracts systematically. An organization taking this approach would have a far greater chance of success than one that occasionally pursued government contracts, without making any serious attempt to learn the ins and outs
    • Identify the key decision-makers in your organization: An effective project manager understands which people in an organization actually have the influence to make a project happen and addresses the interests and concerns of those decision-makers
    • Know your organization’s project selection process: It’s important to understand how your organization decides which projects to execute. It’s critical to how you go about seeking approval for your project and how you present it to decision makers
    • Learn as much about your organization’s project selection criteria: In many organizations, the criteria for project selection are not always clear and quantitative. Look out for opportunities to engage with colleagues and managers who can help you better understand how and by whom decisions about project selection and continuation are made

  • Lesson Summary
  • In considering strategies for project management, bear in mind that:

    • Efficient and effective project management procedures should begin with choosing the right projects, managing them within a program of related projects, and within a portfolio of the entire organization’s projects and programs

    • The strategy of an organization is a picture of its unique purpose in the market, distinguishing it from other competing organizations. All decisions made in the organization about projects, programs, or portfolios should support the organization’s overall strategy. This strategy should, in turn, define the company’s portfolio and daily activities. The management has to be willing to make trade-offs, undertaking some projects and declining or terminating others in order to achieve its strategy

    • Operational effectiveness which involves working faster and cutting costs is not the same as strategy according to Michael Porter. For an organization to compete solely on operational effectiveness is not viable in the long run, because competitors will always catch up (Hammonds 2001)

    • Experts on strategy have explained various reasons why executing a strategy can be so difficult. One issue is that managers usually tend to think of trade-offs as signs of weakness. Also, many organizations are susceptible to the ‘sunk cost fallacy’, refusing to terminate projects that are not in alignment with the company strategy due to the money and resources already spent on them

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Define basic terms used in project initiation
    • Evaluate how the initiation phase matches a project’s overall life cycle
    • Discuss the importance of defining “project success”
    • Describe the elements of a project charter and its role in the initiation phase
    • Identify issues related to project scope
    • Differentiate between adaptive and technical challenges
    • Explain the importance of understanding a project’s context
    • Discuss the potential for the project context to change as you begin the initiation process

  • Project Initiation and the Project Life Cycle
  • Introduction
  • Physics states that light is both particle and wave. Project management also has a similar nature; it is both a series of distinct phases with a clear beginning and end, and a continuous, circular process in which each ending leads to a new beginning. All through a project, a good project manager tries to prepare for changing conditions, rather than simply responding to them as they arise.

    In the more traditional view, which describes project management as a series of sequential phases, with project initiation coming after project selection. You can think of these phases, shown in Figure 3-1, as the particle aspect of project management.

    Figure 3-1: Traditional view of project management (UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-MADISON MADISON, WI)

  • Project Initiation
  • Introduction
  • During the initiation phase of a project, you will have to create the first draft of the following items, which take a high-level view of the project:
    • Project charter: A “single, consolidated source of information” (Richter 2014) for project initiation and planning. It portrays your current knowledge of the project and includes information such as the names of all stakeholders, a statement of your organization’s needs, the history leading up to the project, the project’s purpose, deliverables, and roles and responsibilities. It is sometimes called a project overview statement. It may be helpful to think of the project charter as a contract between the project team and the project sponsors
    • Scope statement: A document that defines the project’s scope. Defining scope, which is really the heart of the initiation phase, will be discussed later in detail
    • Business case: An “argument, usually documented, that is intended to convince a decision maker to approve some kind of action. As a rule, a business case has to articulate a clear path to an attractive return on investment (ROI). At its simplest, a business case could be a spoken suggestion…. For more complex issues, a business case should be presented in a carefully constructed document. A business case document should examine benefits and risks involved with both taking the action and, conversely, not taking the action. The conclusion should be a compelling argument for implementation” (TechTarget n.d.). A business case addresses these fundamental questions: 1) Why this project? 2) Why this project over another project? and 3) Why this project now?

  • Defining Project Success
  • 0
     Advanced issues found
    ▲
     
    Introduction
  • Project managers who are experienced with managing numerous projects over the years are well aware of the importance of defining what ‘success’ truly means for a project and putting effective measures in place as soon as possible. To achieve this, you have to discuss with the people and organizations that will determine whether the project is a success. This often includes clients, individuals or groups with approval authority, or groups of potential customers. Many projects struggle when the engineers responsible say, “We met our objective. We followed the plan as written” but the customer says, “You didn’t give me what I wanted.”

    Over the years, numerous products have been released and thereafter discontinued as specs didn’t fully match the customers’ needs. An example of this is the 2013 release of Facebook Home, a user interface for the Android phone that turned Facebook into the user’s home screen, removing the features, such as docks and app folders, that Android users love. How could the company make such a huge mistake? 

    According to Business Insider, the Facebook Home development team, composed primarily of iPhone users, “was unfamiliar with the features that a normal Android user might get used to, and might not want to lose when they installed Facebook Home” (Carlson 2013). This failure to learn about the customers’ needs had disastrous results. The price of the HTC First, the phone on which Facebook Home came preinstalled, dropped from $99 to 99 cents within a few weeks (Tate 2013). Ultimately, Time magazine named the HTC First one of the “lamest moments in tech” for 2013 (McCracken 2013).

  • The Project Charter
  • Introduction
  • The development of the project charter is one of the most important aspects of project initiation. Inclusion of all relevant stakeholders in the creation process, you will help ensure a consensus on what constitutes project success, relevant constraints (e.g., time and budget), and defining the scope.

    The exact form of a project charter will vary from one organization to another. At some companies, the project charter is a spreadsheet file; in others, a document file. You’ll find many templates for project charters available on the web. According to Managing Projects Large and Small: The Fundamental Skills for Delivering on Budget and on Time, a typical project charter contains some or all of the following:
    • Name of project’s sponsor
    • Relationship between the project’s goals and higher organizational goals
    • Benefits of the project to the organization
    • Project manager’s authority
    • Expected time frame of the work
    • Project manager’s authority
    • Concise description of project deliverables (objectives)
    • Budget, allocations, and resources available to the project team
    • Sponsor’s signature 

      (Harvard Business School Publishing Corporation 2006, 2-3)

  • Managing Project Scope
  • Introduction
  • Project management identifies the triple constants as: time, cost, and scope. It’s impossible to change one without changing at least one of the others. If a project takes twice as long as expected to complete, then the cost will definitely go up. On the other hand, a decision to cut costs, perhaps by using less experienced labor, could lead to a work slowdown, thereby extending the schedule. Such a decision might also result in a change to the project’s scope, perhaps in the form of a lower quality product.

    The initiation phase is too early in the project to determine the precise details about time and cost, but it is a good time to think long and hard about the scope, which is “all of the work that needs to be done to provide the product or service your project is delivering” (Martinez n.d.). Here, you and the project stakeholders might do some blue sky thinking about what your project could possibly achieve, without regard to the constraints of time, cost, and scope. But before too long you’ll need to zero in on a definition of the project’s scope, formalizing it as a scope statement, using the information currently available to you.

    The initiation phase is too early in the project to determine the precise details about time and cost, but it is a good time to think long and hard about the scope, which is “all of the work that needs to be done to provide the product or service your project is delivering” (Martinez n.d.). Here, you and the project stakeholders might do some blue sky thinking about what your project could possibly achieve, without regard to the constraints of time, cost, and scope. But before too long you’ll need to zero in on a definition of the project’s scope, formalizing it as a scope statement, using the information currently available to you.

  • Project Context
  • Introduction
  • According to Merriam-Webster, the term context refers to “the situation in which something happens: the group of conditions that exist where and when something happens.” All projects occur within various contexts—within an organizational context (yours and the customer’s), a market context, a technical context, and a social context. All of these could evolve over the life of a project, and in the permanent whitewater of the modern business world, they probably will. 

    Experienced project managers are attentive to dynamic contexts. They realize that, as contexts change, the project will probably need to be adjusted. Completing the project in accordance with the original objectives could end up being an undesirable outcome, if it turns out that the original objectives no longer match the context of the organization. 

    The potential for changing contexts means that no two projects are the same. You’ll almost certainly find that differences in context will force you to alter your approach to a similar project in some way or another. For example, the fact that you successfully built a hospital in Texas can’t completely prepare you for the experience of building a hospital in San Francisco, where the area’s volatile seismic activity will make you need to consider issues related to earthquake-resistance. In product development, you might find that the customer did not fully understand their needs at the outset.
